review:
[h1]Puzzles[/h1]
They are what make a great walking simulator, they are the back ground to zelda games, they are the integral parts to every point & click adventure. Minesweeper, Zork, chess, D&D. The background of most games, are puzzles. But what makes good puzzles? Certainly someone can have hard puzzles and still have fun puzzles right? Yet here we are, with some of the worst call backs to point and clicks that nobody asked for. Some of these puzzles didn't make sense, and the "clues" were even worse. *Me finding everything to solve the puzzle* Why isn't it working? OH it's because some asshole wrote in some  part of the game that he lied and changed everything, NOW I HAVE TO GO BACK AND RE SOLVE EVERYTHING. NO
[b]NOT EVERYTHING HAS TO BE FUCKING [u]"KEEP TALKING AND NOBODY EXPLODES"[/u][/b]. If the games story wasn't as interesting, I would have stopped when the game wanted me to reconstruct math equations on a spinning wheel. 

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
The art is nice and stylized, the story is great, but the game-play will have you getting out a piece of paper, and doing long division. Fuck off with that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022227319', 'num_games_owned': 4498, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1632526289}
review:
[h1]Overview:[/h1]
'[i]About Elise[/i]' is a first person puzzle game about a girl named well... [i]Elise[/i] who had been abducted and experimented on by a company called '[i]Kiminster Labs[/i]'. You play as the cliched role of her father who goes out in hopes to rescue her from the sinister organization. Throughout his journey, he runs into strange puzzles and places that in all honesty don't really make sense. That however doesn't take away from the fact that the game is actually pretty fun. For a free puzzler, this is one of the better titles although the story does feel a bit lackluster as the plot is only revealed through sheets of paper scattered over the course of the game. The game itself is fairly short and can be finished in less than an hour depending on how good you are at problem solving.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
'[i]About Elise[/i]' focuses heavily on puzzles even though most of them are quite easy and there actually aren't [i]that[/i] many of them in the game. Essentially what you do is go through multiple different rooms each with their own style and puzzle and solve each one in order to progress. It's rather straightforward and doesn't require any intense backtracking as everything you need to solve the puzzle with is confined within the room you're in. Most of the puzzles are extremely easy to figure out except for maybe one or two that actually got me stumped for a bit.

The rooms themselves don't follow any continuity nor logic whatsoever as to why they exist or why they're there. Two levels in particular require a bit of platforming and puzzle solving but have no reason existing in what should be a laboratory. One's filled with deadly water and the other has a seemingly endless abyss. It just makes no sense being there because it's not even realistically possible for these areas to be a workplace nor exist in a facility. It's trivial and doesn't really affect the gameplay if at all but it definitely breaks the immersion for me. I do like lots of variety when it comes to environments but for the story here, it does more harm than good. The overall game is fun however and always gives the player at least something to do at every given time.

[h1]Controls:[/h1]
As basic as most first person games can allow. Move around and interact with items. That's all you need and that's certainly okay with me. They also played a clever trick by leaving notes on-screen when you read them and actually implemented this feature into the games puzzles. That's pretty unique considering what it is. Aside from easy and simple controls that work perfectly fine, I have no other complaints.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]
Personally I don't mind the visuals at all. They're intentionally primitive and minimalistic and it works favorably here. The people are represented in a polygon style and many of the pieces of furniture and such also take a very minimalistic approach. However, the construction bits of the game are far more detailed than everything else which is a bit surprising. Platforms, walls and floors are all textured and have decent detail to them despite everything else being flat and static. I found it pretty interesting cause the items of the world contrast with the world itself which worked rather well here in my opinion.

[h1]Audio:[/h1]
There's not much here either besides the ambience that fills the entire room. Nothing particularly fascinating but nothing out of place either. Huh... I thought there'd be more to say here.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
'[i]About Elise[/i]' is a first person puzzle game with relatively easy puzzles with the occasional challenge here and there. It's fairly short and can be completed in less than an hour as there are only a handful of puzzles and they're all straightforward for the most part. It's a perfectly fine puzzle game that asks for nothing but your time and if you have that to spare and are into puzzle games, this is a nice little one you can try.

review:
Ok first person game mixing some relatively easy platforming and essentially "figure out the right combination to this lock from the nearby clues" puzzles. Puzzles were merely OK. Nothing really creative - just look around to find the clues.

Game could benefit from increased movement speed (at least when running) and an invert-mouse option. Also clicking on interactive objects (cursor turns into a magnifying glass) was rather hit or miss, sometimes taking multiple clicks or trying different angles to come at it from, but fortunately the game tells when you eventually succeed.

I only had trouble with one digit of one combination keypad lock where I found and combined what I believe the two required clues [spoiler](into a 4x4 grid where each square is either blank or has a blue dot) [/spoiler] that still did not make sense to yield a single digit. I brute forced all possible values for that one digit and when I unlocked it, I still couldn't make any sense of how those clues yielded the correct digit that actually solved the puzzle.

review:
[h1]KOSTENLOS[/h1]

"About Elise" ist eine kostenloses First-Person Puzzle-Game.

Wir sind Owen Scott. Unsere Tochter ist entführt worden, weil sie besondere Fähigkeiten zu haben scheint. Wir erwachen auf einem Bett und müssen in mehreren Räumen Rätsel lösen. 

Die etwas an den Haaren herbeigezogene Story, die irgendwie nie so recht begründet erscheint, paßt nur sehr bedingt zum Gameplay. Denn in den Räumen sind immer wieder Zettel versteckt, die meist recht direkt Hinweise auf Lösungswege für die Denkaufgaben liefern. Das sind meist Rätsel, in denen wir auf richtige Zahlenkombinationen oder Reihenfolgen von Schaltern kommen müssen. Wirklich schwer sind die Rätsel eigentlich nicht, manchmal nur merkwürdig bzw. etwas um die Ecke gedacht. In den letzten zwei Räumen kommen noch Hüpfpassagen hinzu, die aber auch machbar ausfallen. 

Die Spielzeit wird sich irgendwo zwischen einer halben und einer Stunde einpendeln. Im Kern sind es nur sechs wesentliche Rätsel-Räume.

Grafisch bewegen wir uns eher auf schwacher Unity-Grafik, wenn auch einige Dinge ästhetisch gut gelöst wurden. Der Sound ist nichts Besonderes, aber durchaus passend. 

Für ein kostenloses Spielchen bietet "About Elise" durchaus gute Rätselunterhaltung, hat sogar hie und da ein paar Designstärken (wie etwa die eingefrorenen Personen) und bietet insofern durchaus mehr als so mancher Low-Price-Titel.

[h1]Wertung:[/h1]
7/10 Atmosphäre
5/10 Story
6/10 Grafik
6/10 Sound
6/10 Spielmechanik
5/10 Balancing
6/10 Spielspass

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]
Ein bißchen Rätselei für lau.

[h1][b]6/10 Gesamtwertung

author: {'steamid': '76561198090468054', 'num_games_owned': 3608, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1524341005}
review:
About Elise (AE) è un puzzle game in prima persona sviluppato da Toni Dominguez, un giovane programmatore di stanza a Barcellona. Dominguez non rientra nella vasta categoria degli "appassionati" informatici, essendo invece esponente del mondo professionistico, come sembra voler sottolineare nettamente sul sito personale. Il lavoro che abbiamo alle mani è stato notato e in qualche modo premiato dal developer spagnolo Zerouno Games, attività sovvenzionata dal Ministerio de Educación, Cultura y Deporte e recentemente nota ai più per il titolo Baobabs Mausoleum. 
Da questa presentazione già si può capire che AE è un titolo molto solido dal punto di vista progettuale. Si riesce a percepire con facilità la cura con cui l'idea è stata ripartita in una struttura dai compartimenti equilibrati e logicamente ordinati, in maniera tale che la progressione non sembra mai né casuale né insoddisfacente. La grafica ha una forte connotazione stilistica che, seppur estremamente semplice, rende riconoscibile il titolo, pur non rinunciando a episodici eye-candy studiati per dare un senso di varietà (le ultime "allucinazioni") o addirittura realismo narrativo (i poster). AE rispetta anche uno dei canoni più diffusi in questo settore del mercato indipendente, ovvero una certa indulgenza nel proporre un qualche livello simbolico, qui particolarmente evidente nelle fasi finali. Lodevole è l'intento di Dominguez di sviare il processo di ricostruzione narrativa del giocatore tramite l'immagine dei manichini in procinto di caduta posta in prossimità dell'accenno documentale al morbo di Alzheimer: una volta giunti alla rivelazione conclusiva, il giocatore ha una bella sensazione nel guardare indietro alle recenti visioni e reinterpretarle a posteriori. Non altrettanto ben implementata è la trovata della scelta singola conclusiva. Personalmente, la brevità dell'esperienza e la densità dell'informazione fornita non mi ha concesso di empatizzare sufficientemente con la situazione proposta: non mi sono dunque trovato nella posizione di dare una risposta "sentita" al doppio finale proposto, e avrei forse preferito che la narrativa si chiudesse in un unico punto, anche considerando la scarsa rigiocabilità di un puzzle game come questo. Il gameplay ottiene un ottimo bilanciamento tra l'impegno richiesto e le ricompense elargite, anche grazie all' idea di inserire un sistema di hint contestualizzati durante le fasi di transizione à la Portal (ascensori); fasi di particolare impegno celebrale sono comunque smorzate da una piacevole soundtrack che ondeggia abilmente tra il misterioso e la sospesa tranquillità.
Come ho tentato di spiegare con questa breve descrizione, è veramente difficile trovare un elemento marcatamente negativo in AE; eppure, allo stesso tempo, è ugualmente complicato descriverlo come una buona esperienza di gioco nel suo insieme. "A videogame is way more than just shooting some aliens", recita la homepage di Dominguez. Purtroppo però, ciò che si evince dal suo lavoro è proprio una ancora non realizzata concezione di questo "way more". L'idea che AE lascia è che sia stato un ottimo modo per promuovere una spiccata capacità individuale nel poter concretamente seguire un progetto videoludico in tutti i suoi aspetti. Ciò di cui si sente però la mancanza è una profondità contenutistica di qualunque tipo capace di muovere l'utente durante la fruizione. Guardiamo ad es. un gioco come Rituals, di durata quasi paragonabile. Rituals esce da gran parte degli empasse di AE proponendo non solo una trama, ma un tema. La scelta finale si può dunque appoggiare non soltanto alla conoscenza degli eventi proposti durante le brevi sessioni di gioco, ma anche a tutta una concezione del mondo del giocatore che va al di là dello schermo stesso. Rituals si prende anche molte più licenze rappresentative, non avendo paura di uscire dalla sua stessa confezione e proponendo invece scene d'improvvisa follia, come quella del suicidio o del salto nella tomba. Sono sicuramente rischi, salti nel vuoto, che possono benissimo essere interpretati come mera pretenziosità o trovate geniali; fatto sta che questa plasticità creativa manca sensibilmente in AE, ed è un peccato.
In definitiva, non è difficile arrivare all'idea che, analogamente a ciò che accade spesso con gli one-man team, Dominguez sia una preziosa aggiunta al settore di cui siamo appassionati, ma come parte di team più ampi che possano supplire dove necessario, in particolare per quanto riguarda l'eccessiva "geometricità" dei concept. 
AE è un buon gioco, ma non è una bella esperienza di gioco, e di questo dovrete essere consapevoli prima di dedicargli un'oretta del vostro tempo libero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250544676', 'num_games_owned': 3672, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1516179361}
review:
'About Elise' is a puzzle game, where the biggest puzzle is why the developer thought anyone would want to play this steaming load of crud.

There's some badly written, badly translated story to it all - I don't think english is their native language given how poor the grammar is, and the amount of incorrectly used words. But even so - it's still a load of pump.

And if you can comprehend the puzzles - then congrats! you win a prize, and that prize is being diagnosed with autism. Of the five I've encountered I could only solve one, and having looked up the solutions they are stupidly convoluted, and just plain boring trying to comprehend them.

After too much time spent on this cack I just turned it off. If you still want to know more about it - it looks bland, and has a naff bit of platforming in one of the most unbelievably designed spaces I've ever seen....that causes instant death....

At least when 'Portal' was being obtuse to make the puzzles harder, it had the kooky nature of it to excuse the fact it didn't make any architectural sense. And it was a game about spatial awareness, and physical logistics.

Here the plaforming is just an annoyance to complete a puzzle,  that again follows a logic known only to madmen.

On the positive side of things - it didn't crash, so...uh...yayyy! They got something right. 

It's free, but its boring, nonsensical rubbish.

Graphics aren't great either but hey, it's free.
The only thing I truly wont forgive the creator for is making me feel like I wasted time from my life which could have been spent with my loved ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198279254828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1512805739}
review:
I'm okay with simple graphics.  Simple graphics are awesome because they run easily on any computer and they allow low budget indie game makers to get a foot in the door.  but these graphics are not just simple, they are also really ugly.  You can be simple and low budget and still be attractive.  Simple-graphics games from the olden days, "retro", and stylistic games are all examples.  This game was butt ugly to look at, and there is no reason for that to be the case other than the duded who made this did not give a fuck.
The controls were really difficult to figure out and I had to quit because I could not for the life of me figure out how to jump over this one bridge thing.  That wouldn't be an issue if this were a platformer or action game that required "physical" challenges, but this game is advertised as story based / puzzle so difficulty moving past that one part was more frustration than fun.  TBH a good way to improve the game play would be to put a "crosshairs" like dot in the middle of the screen like they have in most other first person games.  It makes moving around easier bc you know exactly where you are aimed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198336183474', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1512339064}
review:
Dude, this is disappointing. I totally loved your style, quiet music, muted lights, calm pace. I had some struggling with your hanging calculator in the pad-room, I found that I'm not a citizen of the Jumplovility town anymore, but everything was cool.
And, I have no problems with graphic. Just what I needed.
But, you know. I tried really hard with the last one riddle, it wasn't going the way it should. And after EVERYTHING I've been through, after overcoming the hardest hardship, you just laughed at my face and ended the game. WHAT. This is horrible.
Also, there are no pictures of that Elise. How am I supposed to care about her and about the whole story. O'k, may be it is just my lack of empathy, but I could care more, if I knew, that she was a beautiful goldenhaired princess, or something like that. How about making a sound of crying from invisible ghosty-girl. Or adding other things, I dunno. So it would be a lil more atmospheric, and some russian dude won't be sitting on his floor, long past midnight, trying to understand - for what great purpose in life he just sacrificed his sleep hours.
I recommended that game, when I just started to play, it was so nice, but right now I'm pis*ed. Yet, I like it, when others are annoyed too, so...

review:
About Elise é um jogo curto, em que cada "fase" constitui na resolução de um puzzle diferente. Alguns difíceis, outros não, o jogo chama a atenção pela sua história. A fórmula bem conhecida de cartas espalhadas é utlizada e esse é o recurso que nos faz entender o contexto de tudo o que se está passando. 
Estamos na pele de um pai que está a procura de sua filha, Elise. E com o decorrer da história vamos descobrindo mais sobre onde ele está, o por quê e sobre quem ele é.
O final pode chegar a surpreender alguns, como eu, que não esperava o desfecho. 
A trilha sonora do jogo é bem legal, calma, gostosa de se ouvir enquanto pensa em como solucionar os puzzles. 
Recomendo para uma tarde tediosa de domingo, já que é um jogo rápido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198260712448', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1506799370}
review:
Espero que este juego sea reconocido y todo el mundo haya oido hablar de él, es una verdadera obra maestra
La historia te intriga en las primeras notas, nada más empezar te metes de lleno en un ambiente de misterio y te engancha a seguir jugando para saber qué está pasando y qué ha pasado en ese lugar tan vacío. Llega un punto en el que cada vez que encuentras una nota te vuelves eufórico por poder saber un poco más de lo que sucede. Es imposible no sentir curiosidad ni querer descubrirlo todo
Los rompecabezas tienen la dificultad perfecta para tenerte un rato pensando sin llegar a frustrarte por no poder descifrarlo en poco tiempo, aunque puedes llegar a sentirte atascado en algún punto
Quizás lo más duro son los niveles de plataformas, ya que es muy difícil pasárselos y toca repetirlos muchas veces. De todas formas los puntos de guardado están cerca y la euforia que sientes al llegar no se siente a menudo
La intriga y la curiosidad por la historia que conocemos poco a poco, los rompecabezas tan entretenidos y las ansias de terminar de una vez con las plataformas hacen que no puedas dejar de jugar, metiéndote de golpe en el juego de principio a fin e intensificando la experiencia, emocionándote hasta el límite en pocas horas
La música es demasiado pegadiza y la tendrás en la cabeza todo el día
En resumen, el creador ha hecho un gran trabajo que merece ser reconocido. No tengo nada malo que decir de este juego, sólo que con el nivel de saltar sobre el agua me han salido siete canas.
Merece la pena empezar a jugar, te aseguro que no podrás parar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198276859082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1506506702}
review:
Los primeros pasos en la indutra del videojuego, y más en el panorama independiente, me parecen imposibles. Sin embargo, hay ejemplos de desarrolladores que con esfuerzo y constancia consiguen sacar sus creaciones adelante y se adentran en este mundillo para conseguir luchar por su sueño. 

About Elise es la muestra fehaciente de una idea llevada a cabo, de un modesto proyecto finalizado y el comienzo de la carrera profesional de un creador de videojuegos. El juego tiene buenas ideas y puzzles interesantes. 

Como puntos negativos mencionar, y solo para dar mi opinión como usuario, sin ninguna intención maligna en mis palabras, tal vez las partes de plataformeo, los puntos donde apareces tras fallar en un salto y que necesites elementos ajenos al juego para ayudarte a solucionar ciertos puzzles.
